content.value: Yeah, once it's set up, updates etc are all done automatically. They do offer managed plans, too.

content.value: ah, did not know that one! yeah I feel like all the parts for this are in place; just needs a bit of behind-the-scenes magic to make the setup easier.

content.value: Haha, you're not wrong. It's very well documented, though. Ideally, people find their one techie-friend, have them set it up and it's all smooth sailing from here. It's got good user management too, so basically people could have their own self-hosted hubs.

content.value:
Great @mxbck post On Simplicity https://mxb.at/blog/on-simplicity/ via @adactio

Additionally: simpler approaches are more inclusive & accessible, e.g. #microformats & #indieweb

Fewer abstractions = less to learn before getting started.

Simpler = less time cost on plumbing, tooling; faster to build something more useful.

Less time required = more tinkerable by more people, especially those with less spare time on the margins = more inclusive and accessible.

The @microformats and @indiewebcamp communities have deliberately chosen explicitly simpler approaches:
* microformats.org/wiki/start-simple
* making #microformats2 even simpler: microformats.org/wiki/microformats2-origins#can_we_make_the_simplest_case_simpler
* The IndieWeb Building Blocks approach (https://indieweb.org/building-blocks) rather than a monolithic "Stack"

Choosing explicitly simpler approaches is more than just being smart & efficient, it‚Äôs ethically the right thing to do.

Simpler is a sociopolitical choice to deliberately provide more creative agency to more people. Beyond just more usable by more people, simpler technologies enable more people to build, adapt, alter, evolve their own tools of creation, rather than depending on a select privileged few to do so.

Previously, previously:
* tantek.com/2018/309/t1/complexity-reinforces-privilege
* tantek.com/2010/034/t3/simplicity

Resilient, Declarative, Contextual

Keith J. Grant looks at three key characteristics of CSS that set it apart from conventional programming languages: it‚Äôs resilient; it‚Äôs declarative; and it‚Äôs contextual. Understanding these aspects of the language is key to becoming proficient in CSS.

How and Why We Unit Test Our Sass

Lindsey Wild shares how to unit test your Sass using an open-source tool called True.

From Our Sponsor

Master the UI Design App With The Sketch Handbook

To master all the ins and outs of the Sketch, get yourself a copy of Smashing Magazine‚Äôs The Sketch Handbook by Christian Krammer. The book is packed with practical examples and tutorials covering everything from layer manipulation to responsive baseline grids.

Articles & Tutorials

How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love CSPs

Hidde de Vries explains what CSP (Content Security-Policy) means for the front-end, and for those of us building user interfaces in browsers.

BEM For Beginners: Why You Need BEM

Inna Belaya explains the basic ideas of BEM methodology.

CSS Grid in IE: Debunking Common IE Grid Misconceptions

Daniel Tonon shows how to use CSS grid in a way that will work not only in modern browsers but also in Internet Explorer.

Physics-Based Background Scroll Effects

Will Boyd shows how to create nifty physics-based background scroll effects using Matter.js JavaScript framework.

Don‚Äôt Use The Placeholder Attribute

Eric Bailey clarifies why you should stop using the placeholder attribute.

Accessibility Inspector

This article takes you through the main features of the accessibility inspector in Firefox Developer Tools and how to use it.

How to Test Accessibility of Emails

A good primer on testing for accessibility in your emails by Samantha Connelly.

Promoted Link

Become a CSS Weekly Supporter

As a supporter, you will get an ad-free newsletter ahead of time, your profile will be shown on CSS Weekly‚Äôs website, and you will get a warm, fuzzy feeling knowing that you‚Äôre supporting your favorite newsletter.

Tools

Docz

Docz is a tool that will help you to easily create documentation for your projects.

Variable Fonts

A simple resource for finding and trying variable fonts.

Inspiration

The Layouts of Tomorrow

Max B√∂ck explores some fresh ideas for non-standard layouts using CSS Grid.

Until Next Week

Thanks for reading and thanks for your support, *|FNAME|*.

Happy coding,
Zoran Jambor

Until Next Week

Thanks for reading! If you find the content valuable, please consider supporting the newsletter¬†on Patreon.

Happy coding,
Zoran Jambor

15 Tools and Resources That Designers Are Using In 2018

These tools and resources will help you on your way to become more productive. They will keep you better informed, and keep a step ahead of your competition.

Going Home

A lovely WebGL project made by 302 chanwoo.

Check it out

Roller

Roller is a Sketch plugin that helps you find and fix design inconsistencies.

Check it out

An article by Mathias Bynens that describes some key fundamentals common to all JavaScript engines.

Read it

More Unicode Patterns

Yuan Chuan shows how to create even more fantastic Unicode patterns.

Read it

Theme For A Dream

A beautiful audio-visual web experience using WebGL and Web Audio created for the launch of Natureboy Flako‚Äôs second album ‚ÄúTheme for a Dream‚Äù.

Check it out

Shy blob

Cassie Evans created this super-cute dancing blob demo using tracking.js for face detection. The blob stops dancing when you watch.

Check it out

Free Font: Renner

A beautiful evolution of Futura designed by indestructible type.

Get it

A fun demo by Joe Harry.

Check it out

Distinct Design Systems

An interesting article by Dan Mall about what makes a design system better than any other.

Read it

ColorSpark

Luke Johnson created this tool to help designers find unique colors and striking gradient combinations.

Check it out

World Cup 2018 ‚Ä¶in JSON

The classic API for the World Cup, now with all the new data for 2018.

Check it out

ChromeREPL

In case you missed it: a Sublime Text plugin to execute JavaScript in Google Chrome. By Arthur Carabott.

Check it out

Ok‚ÜíCancel versus Cancel‚ÜíOk

Read it

The Problem with Patterns

Read it

Ellito Dahl shares some best practices for 8pt grid typography.

Check it out

Yett

A small library to control the execution of scripts on a website.

Check it out

Weboji

A library for building your own animoji embedded in Javascript/WebGL applications.

Check it out

Vue Native

A great project by GeekyAnts: a framework to build cross platform native mobile apps using JavaScript. Read more about it in this article.

Check it out

Google PageSpeed Insights ‚Äì Scoring 100/100 with WordPress

Brian Jackson‚Äôs step-by-step guide on how to achieve better website performance.

Read it

A collection of pure bash alternatives to external processes.

content.value:
Frontend developer Max B√∂ck some time ago posted an article on how to create offline-friendly web forms

Using the navigator.onLine method for checking if the user is still connected to the Internet, localStorage and service workers Max outlines a method for alleviating an annoying problem that comes with using forms on the web, particular on mobile platforms:

Losing data and having to fill in a form repetitively if you lose your Internet connection before that form has been submitted.

Having forms retain data in offline situations hence provides tremendous usability benefits.

February 25, 2018 by Bjoern in Front End Development, Software, Web Applications 0 CommentsTagged with: frontend, html5, javascript, progressive web apps, pwa, web applications

Diesen¬†How to turn your website into a PWA¬†Artikel gelesen und den¬†RealFaviconGenerator¬†gesehen. Was es alles gibt. Man lernt echt nie aus.

Bei¬†Herr Paul¬†gelesen, dass auch¬†FrauNessy¬†jeden Tag bloggt. Und¬†Familie Buddenbohm¬†auch. Das l√§uft ja richtig gut mit den Vors√§tzen dieses Jahr.

Nach Fr√ºhst√ºck eine Nerf repariert. Die lassen sich erstaunlich gut √∂ffnen, obwohl alles aus Plastik besteht. Leider ist das Ding schlicht kaputt.

Nerf zum Fr√ºhst√ºck

Dann im dicken Nebel durch halb Hamburg gefahren. Wie so eine klassische Ausfahrt am Sonntag. Laute Musik, wenig Verkehr, dazu der Nebel, das war der entspannteste Teil des Tages.

In Winterhude einen gebrauchten Esstisch abgeholt. Wieder mal, ebay Kleinanzeigen sei dank, 50.000 Treppenstufen gelaufen, denn nat√ºrlich stand der Tisch auf deren Dachboden. Das waren sehr junge Studenten und der hat mir den Tisch zum Auto getragen. So alt bin ich schon, dass man mir den Tisch lieber zum Auto schleppt. Fand ich sehr gut. Die Dame des Hauses allerdings findet den Tisch in echt, vor Ort, nur so mittelgut und ich glaube, wir verkaufen demn√§chst einen Esstisch, aus dritter Hand.

Am Nachmittag waren drei Kinder zu Besuch und endlich haben wir messbar weniger S√º√üigkeiten im Haus. Die sollten √∂fter kommen, endlich wieder Platz im Schrank.

Im Blog¬†Amazon link builder, jetpack und random post widget deaktiviert und guck an, ohne Jetpack ist das Backend sp√ºrbar schneller.

Sp√§ter bemerkt, dass K1 und sein Buddy flei√üig Quatsch auf der Playstation machen, sich neue Accounts anlegen und √ºberhaupt nicht kapieren, was sie da machen, hauptsache klicken, kichern und irgendwas passiert. Am Abend mit K1 alles nochmal gemacht, ich Eltern account, er Unteraccount, aber, und das ist doof, Teile von Fifa funktionieren pl√∂tzlich nicht mehr, dafur muss man wohl mindestens 14 Jahre alt sein, weil irgendwas online passiert und aus rechtlichen Gr√ºnden greift dann in Deutschland eben diese Altersgrenze. Das ist tats√§chlich ziemlich suboptimal, wahrscheinlich feiert er demn√§chst seinen 14. Geburtstag auf der Playstation.
